intro: Ancylocladus coriaceus, commonly known as the thick-leaved yew, is a member of the family Anacardiaceae. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree or shrub characterized by its smooth, reddish bark and glossy, dark green leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers followed by orange-red berries that contain toxic seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical regions, often found in moist, well-drained soils. Its botanical features make it an important species in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
